Award.AwardTitle: Genetic and Molecular Signaling Associated with Cell-cell Fusion in Fungi

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cell-cell fusion is an essential process in most multicellular organisms. In filamentous fungi, formation of cellular networks via fusion of cells is essential for movement of nutrients, which has an immediate applicability to industrial fungus control. In order to interact with one another and respond to environmental cues, these fungi communicate via chemical languages using extracellular signals and cellular responses. This project will study the molecular mechanisms of specific signaling proteins that localize to sites of interaction between cells in order to provide a model to understand signaling between genetically identical cells. The project offers an interdisciplinary training opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doctoral associates (including members of underrepresented groups) who will conduct live cell microscopy, as well as genetics, biochemistry, and molecular biology experiments. They will present their work at national and international conferences, and they will have opportunities to author publications on their research. In addition, biological images and movies developed as a result of the proposed research will be distributed to other Universities and mycological organizations nation-wide as teaching material at undergraduate level and for the public at large.

The elucidation of chemical communication in fungi is important for understanding their role in nature and serves as a molecular paradigm for cell-cell communication. Understanding at molecular scale the homotypic fusion of filamentous fungi has the potential to uncover a new paradigm, that is, a novel mode of establishing specific communication and fusion between related cells. In Neurospora crassa, the attraction of cells to each other, and subsequent fusion, requires a precise regulation of protein localization and activation which is dependent upon reception of chemical signals. Analyses of wild specimens of N. crassa indicate that different chemical languages (i.e. dialects) determine whether or not fusion will occur between genetically different specimens. This project will study the molecular mechanisms of specific signaling proteins that localize to sites of interaction between cells in order to provide a model to understand signaling between genetically identical cells. Using genomic comparisons between wild specimens, the genetic basis of the chemical dialects will be determined.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genetic and Molecular Signalling Associated with Cell-Cell Fusion in Fungi (MCB 1412411)

Cell-cell fusion is an important process during fertilization and also during tissue development in eukaryotic cells, including myoblast fusion during muscle differentiation, fusion between macrophages in the formation of osteoclasts and trophoblast fusion during placental development. In microbes, such as filamentous fungi, sensing and communication between genetically similar (or identical) individuals is important for mediating the development of the multinucleate syncytial vegetative colony that is characteristic of this group of organisms (Fischer et al., Genetics 2018). Germinated asexual spores (germlings) of filamentous fungi, such as Neurospora crassa, engage in chemotropic interactions with cells that share identity at recognition loci. Once contact between germlings is established, cells will initiate the process of cell fusion, in which cell walls are remodeled, plasma membranes fuse, and ultimately the two cells become one with a shared cytoplasm. Cell fusion between hyphae within an individual colony reinforces network architecture and influences the flow of resources throughout the colony. Cell fusion between germlings and between hyphae in filamentous fungi is a fitness attribute that contributes to more rapid colony establishment and exploitation of resources. Over 70 genes have been identified in filamentous fungi (primarily N. crassa) that are involved in kind recognition, chemotropic interactions, and cell fusion (Fig. 1) (Fischer et al. Front Microbiol 2019). While the hypothetical signal(s) and receptor(s) remain to be described, a dynamic molecular signaling network that regulates cell-cell interactions has been revealed, including two conserved mitogen activated protein (MAP)-kinase cascades, a broadly conserved STRIPAK signaling complex, transcription factors, a NADPH oxidase (NOX) complex involved in the generation of reactive oxygen species, cell wall integrity sensors, actin, components of the secretory pathway, and several other proteins. Together these pathways facilitate the integration of extracellular signals, direct polarized growth, and initiate a transcriptional program that reinforces signaling and prepares cells for downstream processes, such as membrane merger, cell fusion and adaptation to heterokaryon formation.

We defined the how the MAP kinase signaling cascades (MAK-2 and MAK-1) contribute to activation of the cell fusion transcription factors (TFs), PP-1 and ADV-1 and, using RNA-sequencing and DNA affinity purification sequencing to identify direct targets of these TFs (Fischer et al., Genetics 2018). These direct target genes included proteins important for signaling and adhesion, plus a number of proteins of unknown biochemical function.  Screening of mutants in these proteins of unknown function revealed that a number of them are important in chemotropic interactions and cell fusion.  Fusion between cells that are identical at recognition loci is rapid and robust. However, chemotropic interactions and cell fusion processes can be blocked when fungal cells have genetic differences at these recognition loci.  We showed that genetic differences at the determinant of communication loci (doc) and hyphal anastomosis-11 (ham-11) locus, coordinately regulated the fusion process through the MAP kinases signaling complexes (Heller et al., PLoS Biol 2018) (Fischer et al., Genetics 2019), indicating an interplay between molecular mechanisms of self and non-self recognition that regulates whether cells cooperate and undergo cell fusion, or whether they compete.  We identified two linked loci that regulates cell wall dissolution when germlings/hyphae undergo adhesion prior to cell wall dissolution. One of these loci encodes a predicted chitin polysaccharide monooxygenase (PMO), the first report of a PMO involved in cell signaling and allorecognition in filamentous fungi (Goncalves et al., Curr Biol 2019).  

This study has contributed to an understanding of the complexities of the regulation of cell fusion and molecular mechanisms of cooperative versus competitive behavior in a simple genetic system.  Additionally, the formation of the interconnected mycelial network is an essential component of the filamentous fungal lifestyle, including those that cause human/animal/plant disease and those species that form a symbiotic relationship with plants and algae, such as mycorrhizae and lichens, respectively. The cell fusion system in N. crassa is an excellent training platform for students, as it includes cell biology, molecular biology, systems biology, genetics and biochemistry. A number of graduate students, post-doctoral associates and undergraduate researchers have contributed to this project, including presenting their results at national and international meetings.  The PI, students and post-doctoral associates have interacted with the general public, particularly on movies on live cell imaging of cell fusion in filamentous fungi and with middle school students in the "Be a Scientist" program.
